_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The management and employees of GRAINCO FS, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Morris Fire Department, Grundy County LEPC or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

The primary acitivity at the facility, which is located on Lisbon Road is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distgributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  The storage and handling system consists of 1-30,000 gallon storage tank, loading riser, associated plumbing and 26-1,000, 41-1,465 gallon nurse tanks. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.  

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 541,304 pounds, this includes the amount of anhydrous ammonia that could be stored in nurse tanks.

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1" published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupantional Safety and Health Administratiion (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident release prevention program.

There has been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  

The

facility has:  a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38; provided state and local authorities the meergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA). In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the Morris Fire Department on the Grundy County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency.  OUr emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and LEPC.
Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Daily visual evaluations are performed on maintenance and operations to asses safe conditions.  There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.

Completed project on 11/20/2009 we added 1 qty 30,000 gallon permanent storage tank to this site totaling 2 - 30,000 permanent storage tanks. The nurse tank inventory will remain as previously reported (26 qty 1,000 gallon tanks, and 41 qty 1,465 gallon tanks)making the total inventory 681,218 pounds).

The facility reported inventory at 11/20/2009 was incorrect.  The facility has 2 permanent storage tanks of 30,000 gal each.  There are only 25ea 1,000 gal tanks and 32ea 1,465 gal tanks.  Total inventory 616,274 pounds corrected 2/1/2011.
